title: Timeline of science fiction
html:
Timeline of science fiction

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
Jump to navigation Jump to search
Various science fiction elements from early history to present

This is a timeline of science fiction as a literary tradition. While the date of the start of science fiction is debated, this list includes a range of Ancient, Medieval, and Renaissance-era precursors and proto-science fiction as well, as long as these examples include typical science fiction themes and topoi such as travel to outer space and encounter with alien life-forms.

2nd century[edit]

A battle scene from A True Story.
Year Event Historical events
  • A True Story was written by Lucian of Samosata, contains a number of SF elements, like travel in space, alien life forms, interplanetary colonization and war, artificial atmosphere, telescopes, and artificial life forms.
  • 106–117: Roman Empire at largest extent under Emperor Trajan after having conquered modern-day Romania, Iraq and Armenia.
  • 126: Hadrian completes the Pantheon in Rome.
  • 161: Marcus Aurelius becomes emperor of the Roman Empire. He is often ranked by historians as one of the greatest Roman emperors.
  • 180–181: Commodus becomes Roman Emperor.

10th century[edit]

In an illustration from The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter, the Moon Princess flies back to her home on the Moon.
Year Event Historical events
  • One Thousand and One Nights has several proto-science fiction stories.[1] One example is "The Adventures of Bulukiya", where the protagonist Bulukiya travels across the cosmos to different worlds much larger than his own world.[2] In "Abu al-Husn and His Slave-Girl Tawaddud", the heroine Tawaddud tells of the mansions of the Moon, and the benevolent and sinister aspects of the planets.[3]
  • 962: Otto the Great crowned the Holy Roman Emperor; he was the first to be crowned Holy Roman Emperor in nearly 40 years.
  • 987: Succession of Hugh Capet to the French Throne and the beginning of Capetian Dynasty.
  • 989: Peace and Truce of God formed, the first movement of the Catholic Church using spiritual means to limit private war, and the first movement in medieval Europe to control society through non-violent means.
  • The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter is considered proto-science fiction.[1] In the story, an old man finds a beautiful baby girl. When she grew to be a young woman, she told her adoptive parents she was not of this world and must return to her people on the Moon.
  • 907: Tang Dynasty ends with Emperor Ai deposed and the Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms period in China commences.
  • 936: Wang Geon unified Later Three Kingdoms of Korea.
  • 938: Ngô Quyền won the battle of Bach Dang against Chinese Southern Han army; this event marked the independence of Vietnam after 1000 years under Chinese rule.

13th century[edit]

Year Event Historical events
c. 1270
  • Ibn al-Nafis publishes Theologus Autodidactus.[4] The story about an autodidactic adolescent feral child incorporates science fiction elements when it depicts an apocalypse.
  • 1204: Sack of Constantinople during the Fourth Crusade, which is considered to be the beginning of the decline of the Byzantine Empire.
  • 1209: The University of Cambridge is founded.
  • 1212: Spanish Christians succeed in defeating the Moors in the long Reconquista campaigns, after the Battle of Las Navas de Tolosa.
  • 1215: The Magna Carta is sealed by John of England, making it one of the first times a medieval ruler is forced to accept limits on his power.
  • 1274: Thomas Aquinas' work, Summa Theologica is published, after his death. Is the main staple of theology during the Middle Ages.

15th century[edit]

Year Event Historical events
1420
  • An anonymous French account of the exploits of Alexander the Great, Vraye ystoire du bon roy Alixandre (The True History of the Good King Alexander) has fanciful stories about him going underwater in a submarine and being carried aloft in a cage, carried by huge Griffins.

Some 15th century writers imitated the 14th century author Geoffrey Chaucer (1340 -1400), such as John Lydgate and Thomas Hoccleve. Notable poets include Stephen Hawes, Alexander Barclay, William Dunbar, Robert Henryson, and Gawin Douglas. John Skelton wrote ironic and satirical works which blended Medieval and Renaissance styles.

17th century[edit]

1624/1626

Kircher's magnetic clock.
Year Event Historical events
1619
  • Johann Valentin Andreae publishes Christianopolis.[5]
  • Dutch East India Company, English East India Company, and Sultanate of Banten all fighting over port city of Jayakarta, which ends up leveled.
1623
  • Tommaso Campanella publishes The City of the Sun.[5]
  • 1620: The Brownist Pilgrims arrive in the Mayflower at Cape Cod.
  • 1626: St. Peter's Basilica in the Vatican completed.
1627
  • Francis Bacon publishes New Atlantis.[6]
  • 1632: Taj Mahal building work started in Agra, India.
  • 1633: Galileo Galilei arrives in Rome for his trial before the Inquisition.
  • 1633–1639: Japan transforms into "locked country".
1634
  • Johannes Kepler publishes A Dream.[6]
  • 1634: Battle of Nördlingen results in Catholic victory.
  • 1636: Harvard University is founded in Cambridge, Massachusetts.
1638
  • Francis Godwin publishes The Man in the Moone.[6]
  • 1643: Louis XIV is crowned King of France. He reigned over the Kingdom of France until his death in 1715, making his reign the longest of any monarch in history at 72 years and 110 days.
  • 1649: King Charles I is executed for High treason, the first and only English king to be subjected to legal proceedings in a High Court of Justice and put to death.
1656
  • Athanasius Kircher publishes Itinerarium Exstaticum (Ecstatic Journey).[7]
1657
  • Savinien de Cyrano de Bergerac's Histoire Comique par Monsieur de Cyrano Bergerac, Contenant les Estats et Empires de la Lune (Cyrano Bergerac's Comical History, containing the States & Empires of the Moon) is published posthumously.[8]
  • 1658: After his father Shah Jahan completes the Taj Mahal, his son Aurangzeb deposes him as ruler of the Mughal Empire.
1666
  • Margaret Cavendish publishes The Blazing World.[7]
  • 1663: Robert Hooke discovers cells using a microscope.
1686
  • Bernard de Fontenelle publishes Discussion of the Plurality of Worlds.[6]
  • 1687: Isaac Newton publishes Philosophiae Naturalis Principia Mathematica.

18th century[edit]

Year Event Historical events
1726
  • Jonathan Swift publishes Gulliver's Travels or Travels into Several Remote Nations of the World. In Four Parts. By Lemuel Gulliver, First a Surgeon, and then a Captain of Several Ships
1733
  • Samuel Madden publishes Memoirs of the Twentieth Century
  • 1735–1739: Russo-Turkish War.
  • 1738: Pope Clement XII issues In eminenti apostolatus, prohibiting Catholics from becoming Freemasons.
  • 1739: Nader Shah defeats the Mughals at the Battle of Karnal and sacks Delhi.
1741
  • Ludvig Holberg publishes Niels Klim's Underground Travels.[6]
  • 1740: Frederick the Great comes to power in Prussia.
  • 1740–1741: Famine in Ireland kills ten percent of the population.
  • 1744: The French attempt to restart the Jacobite rebellion fails.
  • 1748: The Treaty of Aix-La-Chapelle ends the War of the Austrian Succession and First Carnatic War.
1752
  • Voltaire publishes Micromégas.[6]
  • 1750: Peak of the Little Ice Age.
  • 1754–1763: The French and Indian War, the North American chapter of the Seven Years' War, is fought in colonial North America, mostly by the French and their allies against the English and their allies.
  • 1756–1763: The Seven Years' War is fought among European powers in various theaters around the world.
  • 1759: French and Indian War: French commander Louis-Joseph de Montcalm and British commander James Wolfe die during the Battle of the Plains of Abraham.
1765
  • Marie-Anne de Roumier-Robert publishes Voyage de Milord Céton dans les Sept Planètes (Journeys of Lord Seton in Seven Planets).[9]
  • 1760: George III becomes King of Britain.
  • 1761: Marine chronometer invented.
  • 1762–1796: Reign of Catherine the Great of Russia.
  • 1763: The Treaty of Paris ends the Seven Years' War and Third Carnatic War.
  • 1765: The Stamp Act is introduced into the American colonies by the British Parliament.
  • 1769–1770: James Cook explores and maps New Zealand and Australia.
  • 1769–1773: The Bengal famine of 1770 kills one-third of the Bengal population.
1771
  • Louis-Sébastien Mercier publishes The Year 2440.[6]
  • 1771: Richard Arkwright and his partners build the world's first water-powered mill at Cromford.
  • 1775–1783: American Revolutionary War.
  • 1776: The United States Declaration of Independence is adopted by the Continental Congress in Philadelphia.
  • 1778: James Cook becomes the first European to land on the Hawaiian Islands.
1780
  • The Passage from the North to the South Pole is published anonymously in France.[9]
  • 1783: Montgolfier brothers invent hot air balloon.
  • 1785–1795: The Northwest Indian War is fought between the United States and Native Americans.
  • 1787: The United States Constitution is written in Philadelphia and submitted to the states for ratification.
  • 1789: George Washington is elected the first President of the United States; he serves until 1797.
  • 1789: Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen
  • 1789–1799: French Revolution.

19th century[edit]

Year Event Historical events
1805
  • Jean-Baptiste Cousin de Grainville publishes The Last Man.[6]
  • Napoleon becomes First Consul of France in 1800 and then Emperor of France in 1804.[10]
  • 1801: Giuseppe Piazzi discovers the dwarf planet Ceres. – Italy
  • 1801: Thomas Jefferson elected President of the United States by the House of Representatives, following a tie in the Electoral College – United States
  • 1804: World population reaches 1 billion.
  • 1804: First steam locomotive begins operation.
  • 1805: The Battle of Trafalgar eliminates the French and Spanish naval fleets and allows for British dominance of the seas, a major factor for the success of the British Empire later in the century.
1814
  • E. T. A. Hoffmann publishes The Automata[11]
1816
  • E. T. A. Hoffmann publishes The Sandman (short story)[11]
1818
  • Mary Shelley publishes Frankenstein.[6]
  • Jane Austen dies in 1817.[10]
  • Napoleon is defeated at Waterloo in 1815. United States buys Florida from Spain in 1819.[10]
1826
  • Mary Shelley publishes The Last Man.[6]
  • Charles Babbage develops the concept of the difference engine, the world's first computer in 1822.[10]
1827
  • Jane Webb Loudon publishes The Mummy!.[6]
1835
  • Edgar Allan Poe publishes The Unparalleled Adventure of One Hans Pfaall.[12]
1839
  • Edgar Allan Poe publishes the short story "The Conversation of Eiros and Charmion".[12]
1843
  • Edgar Allan Poe publishes The Tell-Tale Heart
1844
  • Nathaniel Hawthorne publishes Rappaccini's Daughter.
1845
  • Edgar Allan Poe publishes The Raven
1848
  • Edgar Allan Poe publishes Eureka: A Prose Poem.[6]
  • The Revolutions of 1848 occur.[10]
1851
  • Jules Verne publishes A Voyage in a Balloon.[13]
  • Great Exhibition held in London.
  • Louis-Napoleon comes to power in France.[13]
1859
  • Hermann Lang publishes The Air Battle: a Vision of the Future.[14]
1864
  • Camille Flammarion publishes Real and Imaginary Worlds[9]
1865
  • Jules Verne publishes From the Earth to the Moon.[6]
  • American Civil War is fought from 1861 to 1865. It introduces mechanized warfare[13] and ironclad ships to battle.
1868
  • Edward S. Ellis publishes The Steam Man of the Prairies, the first SF dime novel.[13]
1870
  • Jules Verne publishes Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea.[6]
1871
  • George T. Chesney publishes the novella The Battle of Dorking.[6]
  • Edward Bulwer-Lytton publishes The Coming Race.[6]
1872
  • Samuel Butler publishes Erewhon[13]
1886
  • Robert Louis Stevenson publishes Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde[13]
1887
  • Camille Flammarion publishes Lumen.[6]
  • W. H. Hudson publishes A Crystal Age.[6]
1888
  • Edward Bellamy publishes Looking Backward, 2000-1887.[6]
1889
  • Mark Twain publishes A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court.[6]
  • Camille Flammarion publishes Uranie.[14]
1890
  • William Morris publishes News from Nowhere.[6]
1894
  • Camille Flammarion publishes Omega: The Last Days of the World.[14]
1895
  • H. G. Wells publishes The Time Machine.[6]
  • J.-H. Rosny aîné publishes Un Autre Monde ("Another World").[6]
  • The Lumière Brothers show the first motion films in 1895.[13]
1896
  • H. G. Wells publishes The Island of Doctor Moreau.[6]
1897
  • Kurd Lasswitz publishes On Two Planets.[6]
1898
  • H. G. Wells publishes The War of the Worlds.[6]

1900s[edit]

Year Event Historical events
1900
  • L. Frank Baum publishes The Wonderful Wizard of Oz.[15]
  • The British Empire engages in the Boer War.
  • The 16th World Exhibition takes place in Paris.
  • Art Nouveau challenges Jugendstil.[15]
1901
  • H. G. Wells publishes The First Men in the Moon.[6]
  • M. P. Shiel publishes The Purple Cloud.[6]
1902
  • Georges Méliès shows the film A Trip to the Moon (Le Voyage dans la Lune).[16]
1903
  • H.G. Wells publishes The Land Ironclads
  • The Wright brothers usher in the era of heavier than air flight with their successful flight of Kitty Hawk, North Carolina.
1905
  • Rudyard Kipling publishes the short story "With the Night Mail".[17]
  • Albert Einstein postulates the light quantum, proves that atoms exist, and publishes on the Special Theory of Relativity.[18]
1907
  • Jack London publishes The Iron Heel.[17]
  • William James publishes Pragmatism[18]
  • Robert Hugh Benson publishes Lord of the World, one of the first works of dystopian fiction.[19]
  • The first helicopter, designed by Paul Cornu, flies for 20 seconds.
  • Leo Baekeland invents Bakelite, the first commercially produced plastic.
1909
  • E. M. Forster publishes the novella The Machine Stops.[17]
  • Filippo Tommaso Marinetti founds the Futurist Movement with the publication of Il Manifesto del Futurismo (Futurist Manifesto).[20]
  • James William Barlow publishes the book The Immortals' Great Quest. Translated from an Unpublished Manuscript in the Library of a Continental University (i.e. written by) by James William Barlow. London: Smith, Elder & Co.[21]
  • Ezra Pound publishes Evolutions[18]
  • Henry Ford produces the Model T.[18]

1910s[edit]

Ralph 124C 41+
Serialized in Modern Electrics
AuthorHugo Gernsback
CountryUnited States
LanguageEnglish
GenreScience fiction novel
Publication date
1911
Media typePrint (hardback & paperback)
Preceded bynone 
Followed bynone 
Year Event Historical events
1910
  • Thomas Edison's film company produces the first film adaptation of Frankenstein.[22]
  • Marie Curie publishes Treatise on Radiography.[22]
  • Mark Twain dies.
  • Florence Nightingale dies.
  • Manet and the Post-Impressionists opens at the Grafton Galleries in London.
1911
  • Hugo Gernsback publishes Ralph 124C 41+ in serial form in Modern Electrics.[17]
  • F. W. Mader publishes Wunderwelten in which a crew of young astronauts travels to Alpha Centauri at faster-than-light speeds.[22]
1912
  • J. D. Beresford publishes The Hampdenshire Wonder.[17]
  • Garrett P. Serviss publishes The Second Deluge.[17]
  • Edgar Rice Burroughs publishes the novella Under the Moons of Mars.[17]
  • Arthur Conan Doyle publishes The Lost World, which gives the name to the Lost World subgenre of science fiction. Ironically, it is also one of the last Lost World novels to be published.[22]
  • John Jacob Astor, Jacques Futrelle, and W. T. Stead, all early science fiction authors, die in the sinking of the Titanic.[22]
1913
  • Bernhard Kellermann publishes Der Tunnel (The Tunnel) in which a transatlantic tunnel is built, tying North America and Europe together.[22]
  • Hugo Gernsback ceases publication of Modern Electrics. He then founds Electrical Experimenter.[22]
  • Paul Scheerbart publishes Lesabendio, ein Asteroidenroman (Lesabendio, An Asteroid Novel).
1914
  • George Allan England publishes Darkness and Dawn.[17]
  • H. G. Wells publishes The World Set Free.[22]
  • Archduke Franz Ferdinand is assassinated in Sarajevo.[22]
1915
  • Charlotte Perkins Gilman publishes Herland.[17]
  • Jack London publishes The Scarlet Plague.[17]
  • Guy Thorne predicts armored tanks in his novel The Cruiser on Wheels.[23]
  • The Lusitania is sunk.[23]
  • Albert Einstein publishes General Theory of Relativity.[23]
  • Germany develops poison gas weapons.[23]
  • Zeppelins begin flying.[23]
1916
  • Gustav Meyrink publishes The Green Face in Austria.[23]
  • The film Homunculus depicts an artificial being devoid of a motivating spirit.[23]
  • Otto Witt launches Hugin, widely considered the first true science fiction magazine.[23]
  • Tanks make their first appearance in World War I.[23]
1917
  • Victor Rousseau Emanuel publishes The Messiah of the Cylinder.[23]
  • The movie Himmelskibet (The Airship) is produced during the middle of World War I.[23]
  • T. S. Eliot publishes Prufrock and Other Observations.[23]
  • The United States enters World War I.[23]
  • Vladimir Lenin leads the Bolshevik Revolution in Russia.[23]
1918
  • Abraham Merritt publishes the novella The Moon Pool.[17]
  • Alraune is produced as a film twice in 1918. One is made in Hungary by Michael Curtiz.[23]
  • William Hope Hodgson is killed in World War I.
  • Lytton Strachey publishes Eminent Victorians.[23]
  • British women get the vote.[23]
  • The United States Postal Service begins airmail service between Washington, D.C. and New York.[23]
1919
  • City of Endless Night by Milo Hastings is serialized in True Story magazine.[23]
  • The atom is split for the first time by Ernest Rutherford.[23]

1920s[edit]

The Maschinenmensch from the 1927 film Metropolis
Year Event Historical events
1920
  • Karel Čapek publishes R.U.R.: A Fantastic Melodrama.[17]
  • W. E. B. Du Bois publishes the short story "The Comet".[17]
  • David Lindsay publishes A Voyage to Arcturus.[17]
  • The film Der Golem is released.[24]
  • Argosy and All-Story Weekly combine and become Argosy All-Story Weekly.[24]
1921
  • Homer Eon Flint and Austin Hall publish "The Blind Spot" in Argosy All-Story Weekly.[24]
  • J. D. Beresford publishes Revolution.[24]
1922
  • Alexei Tolstoy publishes Aelita.[24]
  • T. S. Eliot publishes The Waste Land.[24]
  • Sinclair Lewis publishes Babbitt.[24]
  • Mahatma Gandhi goes to jail.[24]
  • Benito Mussolini comes to power in Italy.[24]
1923
  • E. V. Odle publishes The Clockwork Man.[17]
  • P. Anderson Graham publishes The Collapse of Homo Sapiens.[24]
  • Ronald Knox publishes Memories of the Future.[24]
  • H. G. Wells publishes Men Like Gods.[24]
  • Hugo Gernsback dedicates an entire issue of the journal Science and Invention to science fiction. This leads directly to the publication of Amazing Stories.[24]
  • The United States continues its policy of isolationism.[24]
  • Inflation explodes in Germany.[24]
  • Mustafa Kemal is elected President of Turkey.[24]
1924
  • Yevgeny Zamyatin publishes We.[17]
1925
  • Hugo Gernsback publishes Ralph 124C 41+ as a monograph.[25]
  • The New Yorker begins publication.[25]
  • Electrical recordings become a reality.[25]
  • Kodak develops 16mm film stock.[25]
  • John Logie Baird develops the technology to transmit images by television.[25]
  • Adolf Hitler publishes Mein Kampf.[25]
  • Sergei Eisenstein releases the silent film Battleship Potemkin.[25]
  • The Irish Civil War ends.[25]
1926
  • Hugo Gernsback launches Amazing Stories.[17]
  • Robert M. Coates publishes The Eater of Darkness.[25]
  • Guy Dent publishes Emperor of the If.[25]
  • Fritz Lang releases his ground-breaking classic Metropolis.[25]
  • Thea von Harbou serializes the screenplay of the silent film Metropolis directed by her husband, Fritz Lang.[25]
  • Edgar Rice Burroughs publishes The Moon Maid.[25]
  • Charlotte Haldane publishesMan's World.[25]
  • Reginald Glossup publishes The Orphan of Space.[25]
  • A. A. Milne publishes Winnie-the-Pooh.[25]
  • Robert H. Goddard successfully launches a liquid-fuel rocket in the United States.[25]
  • Leon Trotsky is ejected from the Politburo.[25]
  • Rudolph Valentino dies.[25]
1927
  • John Taine publishes Quayle's Invention and The Gold Tooth.[25]
1928
  • E. E. Smith publishes The Skylark of Space.
  • Victor Gollancz founds Victor Gollancz Ltd, which publishes science fiction from its very first year onward.[25]
  • Joseph Stalin comes to power in the Soviet Union.[25]
  • Walt Disney releases the first Mickey Mouse cartoon.[25]
1929
  • Buck Rogers in the 25th Century begins publication as a comic strip.[25]
  • Hugo Gernsback coins the term science fiction.[25]
  • Kay Burdekin publishes The Rebel Passion.[25]
  • Jack Williamson publishes The Girl from Mars.[25]
  • S. Fowler Wright publishes The World Below.[25]
  • Fritz Lang releases the realistic-looking film The Woman in the Moon.[25]
  • William Faulkner publishes The Sound and the Fury.[25]
  • The Wall Street Crash occurs.[25]
  • The Graf Zeppelin circumnavigates the globe.[25]

1930s[edit]

First issue of Astounding Stories of Super-Science, dated January 1930. The cover art is by Hans Waldemar Wessolowski.
Year Event Historical events
1930
  • Olaf Stapledon publishes Last and First Men.[17]
  • The F. E. Smith, 1st Earl of Birkenhead publishes The World in 2030.[26]
  • John Taine publishes The Iron Star.[17]
  • Astounding Science-Fiction begins publication.[17]
  • The film Just Imagine is released; it is badly received and slows the advance of science fiction as a film genre.[26]
  • Science Wonder Stories and Air Wonder Stories merge to become Wonder Stories magazine.[26]
  • Astounding Stories of Super Science begins publication.[26]
  • The Nationalist Socialist Party comes to power in Germany.[26]
  • Mahatma Gandhi marches across India in protest of the Salt Tax.[26]
1931
  • James Whale releases his classic film adaptation of Frankenstein.[26]
  • Science and Invention ceases publication.[26]
  • Astounding Stories of Super Science changes its title to Astounding Stories.[26]
1932
  • Aldous Huxley publishes Brave New World.[17]
  • Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde is made into a film.[26]
  • Adolf Hitler is defeated in presidential elections in Germany but holds onto a majority in the Reichstag.[26]
  • Unemployment riots break out in England.[26]
  • Franklin D. Roosevelt wins an overwhelming majority in the United States presidential elections.[26]
1933
  • John Collier publishes the post-holocaust novel Tom's A-Cold (published as Full Circle in the United States).[26]
  • James Whale directs the film version of The Invisible Man by H. G. Wells.[26]
  • Street and Smith purchase Astounding Stories and retool its editorial policy which raises its prominence in the field of science fiction.[26]
  • Adolf Hitler becomes Chancellor of Germany.[26]
  • The Hitler Youth is formed in Germany.[26]
  • Germany and Japan withdraw from the League of Nations.[26]
1934
  • Murray Leinster publishes the short story "Sidewise in Time".[17]
  • Stanley G. Weinbaum publishes the short story "A Martian Odyssey".[17]
  • The Skylark series by E. E. Smith ends with the publication of Skylark of Valeron.[26]
  • E. E. Smith begins publication of his Lensman series with "Triplanetary" which is serialized in Amazing magazine.[26]
  • Jack Williamson begins publication of his Legion of Space series.[26]
  • Flash Gordon, a comic strip about a space opera adventure first published January 7, 1934.
1935
  • Olaf Stapledon publishes Odd John.[17]
  • Joseph O'Neill publishes Land under England, a Lost World novel that provides the backdrop for a sharp political satire.[27]
  • Maurice Renard's Le mains d'Orlac (The Hands of Orlac) is made into the film Mad Love.[27]
  • Porgy and Bess by Ira Gershwin opens.[27]
  • Germany strips is Jewish citizens of their citizenship.[27]
  • The Dust Bowl strikes the middle of North America.[27]
1936
  • Things to Come, directed by William Cameron Menzies, is released.[17]
  • Paul Gurk publishes Tuzub 37.[27]
  • Karel Čapek publishes Valka s mloky (War with the Newts).[27]
  • Flash Gordon appears on film for the first time.[27]
  • Wonder Stories is sold off and is recast as Thrilling Wonder Stories taking a definite turn towards stories and images of monsters and adventures.[27]
1937
  • J. R. R. Tolkien publishes The Hobbit
  • Flash Gordon appears in the first book version of the series in Flash Gordon in the Caverns of Mongo.[27]
  • John W. Campbell Jr. becomes editor of Astounding Stories; he promptly changes the title to Astounding Science Fiction.[27]
  • George Orwell publishes The Road to Wigan Pier.[27]
  • The Spanish Civil War erupts.[27]
  • Germany aligns with Benito Mussolini.[27]
  • Germany occupies the Rhineland.[27]
1938
  • John W. Campbell Jr., writing under the pseudonym "Don A. Stuart", writes the novella Who Goes There?.[17]
  • C. S. Lewis publishes Out of the Silent Planet.[28]
  • Orson Welles dramatises H.G. Wells' The War of the Worlds on the radio and causes alleged widespread panic.[27]
  • Germany annexes Austria.[27]
  • Germany occupies the Sudetenland.[27]
1939
  • A. E. van Vogt publishes Black Destroyer
  • Stanley G. Weinbaum publishes The New Adam.[17]
  • Startling Stories is launched.[27]
  • The Alice in Wonderland series by Lewis Carroll is parodied in Adolf in Blunderland.[27]
  • Hitler annexes the rest of Czechoslovakia.[27]
  • Hitler invades Poland.[27]
  • France and Britain declare war on Germany.[27]

1940s[edit]

Year Event Historical events
1940
  • Robert A. Heinlein publishes the short story "The Roads Must Roll".[17]
  • Robert A. Heinlein publishes the short story "If This Goes On—".[17]
  • A. E. van Vogt publishes Slan as a serial; it is later published as a monographic volume in 1946.[17]

  • Paris falls to the German army.[29]
  • Leon Trotsky is assassinated in Mexico by Soviet agents.[29]
  • Walt Disney makes Fantasia.[29]
1941
  • Isaac Asimov publishes the short story "Nightfall".[17]
  • L. Sprague de Camp publishes Lest Darkness Fall.[17]
  • Robert A. Heinlein publishes the short story "Universe".[17]
  • Theodore Sturgeon publishes the short story "Microcosmic God".[17]
  • Phil Stong publishes the first major anthology of science fiction short stories.[29]

  • John W. Campbell Jr. shuts down Unknown to preserve paper so as to keep Astounding Science Fiction in print.[29]
  • The United States enters World War II after Japan bombs Pearl Harbor.[29]
  • Russia enters World War II after Germany invades its Western border.[29]
1942
  • Isaac Asimov begins publishing the short stories that later were compiled into his seminal work Foundation.[17]
  • Robert A. Heinlein writes Beyond This Horizon then ceases writing science fiction to focus on war-related work.[29]

  • Austin Tappan Wright publishes Islandia (novel).[29]
  • Peter Vansittart publishes I am the World.[29]
1943
  • The Gremlins is written by Roald Dahl for Walt Disney Productions.[29]
  • Batman (serial) is released by Columbia Pictures as a 15 episode serial.[29]
  • Heavily armed German forces occupy the Warsaw Ghetto.[29]
1944
  • C. L. Moore publishes the short story "No Woman Born".[17]
  • Clifford Simak begins publishing City in serial format in Astounding Science Fiction.[29]
  • Aldous Huxley publishes Time Must Have a Stop.[29]
  • Olaf Stapledon publishes Sirius.[29]
  • Philip Wylie publishes Night Unto Night.[29]
  • Adolf Hitler unleashes the V-2 rocket on London in September 1944.[29]
1945
  • Murray Leinster publishes the novella First Contact.[30]
  • A. E. van Vogt publishes The World of Null-A as a serial in Astounding Science Fiction and later as a book in 1948.[31]
  • C. S. Lewis publishes That Hideous Strength.[31]
  • George Orwell publishes Animal Farm (novel).[31]
  • The dropping of Atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki end World War II and usher in the Atomic Age.[31]
1946
  • The Best of Science Fiction anthology, edited by Groff Conklin, is published.[30]
  • A. E. van Vogt publishes Slan in book format.[31]
  • E. E. Smith publishes The Skylark of Space in book format.[31]
  • McComas and Healy publish Adventures in Time and Space, an anthology of short stories considered seminal in the genre.[31]
  • Pat Frank publishes Mr. Adam.[31]
  • New Worlds begins publication in England.[31]
  • ENIAC, the world's first electronic computer, is built.[31]
1947
  • Robert A. Heinlein publishes Rocket Ship Galileo.[30]
  • Gnome Press becomes the most successful small press to publish science fiction content.[31]
  • J. O. Bailey publishes Pilgrims in Space and Time, the first academic analysis of science fiction.[31]
  • Fantasy Fiction, a short-lived science fiction magazine, begins publication. Despite its short run, it publishes the works of established writers Isaac Asimov, A. E. van Vogt, and Murray Leinster, as well as the first published story by Cordwainer Smith, "Scanners Live in Vain", who had not been able to get published in more established SF magazines.[31]
1948
  • Judith Merril publishes the short story "That Only a Mother".[30]
  • Founded in 1947, Shasta Publishers is publishing works by major SF authors by 1948, including Robert A. Heinlein, L. Sprague de Camp, and Alfred Bester. Shasta rejects L. Ron Hubbard's first Dianetics volume.[31]
  • Astounding Science Fiction publishes Dianetics after it is rejected by Shasta Publishers.[31]
1949
  • Everett Bleiler and T. E. Dikty edit and publish The Best Science Fiction Stories.[30]
  • George Orwell publishes Nineteen Eighty-Four.[30]
  • H. Beam Piper publishes the short story "He Walked Around the Horses".[30]
  • George R. Stewart publishes Earth Abides.[30]
  • Jack Vance publishes the short story "The King of Thieves".[30]
  • The Magazine of Fantasy and Science Fiction begins publication.[30][31]
  • Mao Zedong seizes control of China.[31]
  • South Africa adopts apartheid.[31]
  • Albert Einstein publishes Generalized Theory of Gravitation.[31]
  • Carol Reed directs the British film noir movie The Third Man.[31]

Year Event Historical events

  • Star Trek: The Next Generation launches on television in the United States.[47]
  • Alan Moore publishes his Watchmen in the U.S. comics market.[47]
  • Seventy countries sign the Montreal Accord pledging to reduce Chlorofluorocarbon emissions.[47]
1988
  • John Barnes publishes Sin of Origin.[48]
  • Sheri S. Tepper publishes The Gate to Women's Country.[48]
  • Robert A. Heinlein dies.[47]
  • Red Dwarf begins airing in Great Britain.[47]
  • Ronald Reagan travels to the Soviet Union and signs a major agreement to reduce the United States and Russia's nuclear arsenals.[47]
  • Severe droughts and massive heat wave gripping the Midwest and Rocky Mountain states. The crisis reaches its peak with the Yellowstone fires of 1988.
  • Discovery is launched as first post-Challenger disaster Space Shuttle flight.
  • The Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty goes into effect.
1989
  • Orson Scott Card publishes The Folk of the Fringe.[48]
  • Geoff Ryman publishes The Child Garden.[48]
  • Dan Simmons publishes Hyperion.[48]
  • Bruce Sterling publishes the short story "Dori Bangs".[48]
  • Sheri S. Tepper publishes Grass.[48]
  • Locus Magazine documents a 50% per year increase in the number of science fiction books being published.[47]
  • Doctor Who is cancelled.[47]
  • The Berlin Wall is torn down.[47]
  • The tanker ship Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska's Prince William Sound, dumping 10.8 million US gallons of oil into pristine wildlife habitat.

1990s[edit]

Year Event Historical events
1990
  • Colin Greenland publishes Take Back Plenty.[48]
  • Kim Stanley Robinson publishes Pacific Edge.[48]
  • Sheri S. Tepper publishes Raising the Stones.[48]
  • Brian Stableford publishes his first Werewolves of London series.[49]
  • Total Recall is released.[49]
  • Eidolon (Australian magazine) is launched in Australia.[49]
  • Nelson Mandela is released from prison after 27 years of captivity.[49]
  • Boris Yeltsin is elected President of Russia.[49]
  • Iraq invades Kuwait.[49]
  • East and West Germany are reunited.[49]
  • The Channel Tunnel workers digging from both ends meet in the middle.[49]
  • The first World Wide Web-site comes online.[50]
  • Hubble Space Telescope launched during STS-31, a Space Shuttle Discovery mission.
1991
  • Stephen Baxter publishes Raft.[48]
  • Emma Bull publishes Bone Dance.[48]
  • Pat Cadigan publishes the short story "Dispatches from the Revolution".[48]
  • Michael Crichton publishes Jurassic Park.[48]
  • Gwyneth Jones publishes White Queen.[48]
  • Brian Stableford publishes Sexual Chemistry: Sardonic Tales of the Genetic Revolution.[48]
  • James Cameron releases Terminator 2: Judgment Day.[49]
  • Operation Desert Storm launches the beginning of the Gulf War.[49]
  • The Cold War ends as the USSR is dissolved.
1992
  • Greg Egan publishes Quarantine.[48]
  • Nancy Kress publishes the short story "Beggars in Spain".[48]
  • Maureen McHugh publishes China Mountain Zhang.[48]
  • Kim Stanley Robinson publishes Red Mars.[48]
  • Neal Stephenson publishes Snow Crash.[48]
  • Vernor Vinge publishes A Fire Upon the Deep.[48]
  • Connie Willis publishes Doomsday Book.[48]
  • Isaac Asimov dies.[49]
  • Yugoslavia dissolves into a number of smaller states.[51]
  • Political reforms in South Africa unfold.[51]
  • Riots break out in Los Angeles after police are caught beating Black man Rodney King on film.[51]
  • 1992 — U.S. presidential election, 1992: Bill Clinton elected president, Al Gore elected vice president.
1993
  • Eleanor Arnason publishes Ring of Swords.[48]
  • Nicola Griffith publishes Ammonite.[48]
  • Peter F. Hamilton publishes Mindstar Rising.[48]
  • Nancy Kress publishes Beggars in Spain.[48]
  • Paul J. McAuley publishes Red Dust.[48]
  • Paul Park publishes Coelestis.[48]
  • Star Trek: Deep Space Nine begins airing in the United States.[52]
  • A truck bomb explodes in the parking garage under the World Trade Center in New York City, killing six people and injuring over a thousand.
  • 1993 — Branch Davidians standoff and fire near Waco, Texas, resulting in the deaths of 81 people including their leader, David Koresh.
1994
  • Kathleen Ann Goonan publishes Queen City Jazz.[48]
  • Elizabeth Hand publishes Waking the Moon.[48]
  • Mike Resnick publishes A Miracle of Rare Design.[53]
  • Melissa Scott publishes Trouble and Her Friends.[53]
  • Stargate is released in cinemas.[51]
  • Multiracial elections are held for the first time in South Africa.[51]
  • Civil war breaks out in Rwanda.[51]
1995
  • Greg Egan publishes Permutation City.[53]
  • Ken MacLeod publishes The Star Fraction.[53]
  • Melissa Scott publishes Shadow Man.[53]
  • Neal Stephenson publishes The Diamond Age.[53]
  • Star Trek: Voyager begins airing in the United States.[54]
  • Oklahoma City bombing kills 168 and wounds 800. The bombing is the worst domestic terrorist incident in U.S. history, and the investigation results in the arrests of Timothy McVeigh and Terry Nichols.
1996
  • Orson Scott Card publishes Pastwatch: The Redemption of Christopher Columbus.[53]
  • Kathleen Ann Goonan publishes The Bones of Time.[53]
  • Mary Doria Russell publishes The Sparrow.[53]
1997
  • Wil McCarthy publishes Bloom.[53]
  • Paul J. McAuley publishes Child of the River.[53]
1998
  • Graham Joyce and Peter F. Hamilton publish the short story "Eat Reecebread".[53]
  • Keith Hartman publishes the short story "Sex, Guns, and Baptists".[53]
  • Nalo Hopkinson publishes Brown Girl in the Ring.[53]
  • Ian R. MacLeod publishes the short story "The Summer Isles".[53]
  • Brian Stableford publishes Inherit the Earth.[53]
  • Bruce Sterling publishes Distraction.[53]
  • Howard Waldrop publishes "US".[53]
1999
  • Greg Bear publishes Darwin's Radio.[53]
  • Neal Stephenson publishes Cryptonomicon.[53]
  • Vernor Vinge publishes A Deepness in the Sky.[53]
  • Matrix is released.[55]
  • Teenage students Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold murder 13 other students and teachers at Columbine High School, sparking an international debate on gun control and bullying.
  • The world prepares for the possible effects of the Y2K bug in computers, which was feared to cause computers to become inoperable and wreak havoc. The problem isn't as large as theorized, preparations are successful, and disaster is averted.

2000s[edit]

Year Event Historical events
2000
  • Nalo Hopkinson publishes Midnight Robber, a coming-of-age story set in a Caribbean-settled colony world.[53]
  • Ursula K. Le Guin publishes The Telling.[53]
  • Ken MacLeod publishes Cosmonaut Keep.[53]
2001
  • Terry Bisson publishes the short story "The Old Rugged Cross".[53]
  • Ted Chiang publishes the short story "Hell is the Absence of God".[53]
  • John Clute publishes Appleseed.[53]
  • Mary Gentle publishes Ash: A Secret History.[53]
  • Maureen McHugh publishes Nekropolis.[53]
  • China Miéville publishes Perdido Street Station.[53]
  • Geoff Ryman releases mundane science fiction manifesto, calling for hard science fiction that depicts plausible technologies
  • Joan Slonczewski publishes Brain Plague.[53]
  • Douglas Adams dies
  • September 11: The United States is attacked by Al Qaeda using commandeered jet planes that were crashed into the World Trade Center.
2002
  • Greg Egan publishes Schild's Ladder.[53]
  • Jon Courtenay Grimwood publishes Effendi.[53]
  • Kim Stanley Robinson publishes The Years of Rice and Salt.[53]
2003
  • Space Shuttle Columbia disintegrates upon re-entry to the Earth's atmosphere, killing all seven astronauts and resulting in a 29-month suspension of the Space Shuttle program.
  • The United States, United Kingdom, Australia and Poland invades Iraq marking the start of Operation Iraqi Freedom.
2004
2005
  • Hurricane Katrina devastates the Louisiana, Mississippi, and Alabama coastlines killing at least 1,836 people and causing $81 billion in damage, making it the costliest natural disaster in U.S. history. Weeks later, Hurricane Rita causes $10 billion damage along the Louisiana and Texas coastlines. In October, Hurricane Wilma kills 35 and causes $20 billion in damage in Florida.
2006
2007
  • Oxford University Press publishes what is said to be "the first historical dictionary devoted to science fiction": Brave New Words.[56]
  • A South Korean student shoots and kills 32 other students and professors in the Virginia Tech massacre before killing himself. It stands as the worst mass shooting in U.S. history until 2012 and spurs a series of debates on gun control and journalism ethics.
2008
  • Iron Man is released
  • Arthur C. Clarke dies
  • U.S. presidential election, 2008: Barack Obama is elected president, and Joe Biden vice president.
2009
  • J. J. Abrams' Star Trek is released.[57]

2010s[edit]

Year Event Historical events
2010
  • Social media website Instagram founded
  • The Deepwater Horizon oil rig in the Gulf of Mexico explodes, spilling millions of gallons of oil into the sea. The spill becomes the worst oil spill in American history.
2011
  • Osama bin Laden, leader of al-Qaeda and mastermind of the September 11 attacks, is killed in Abbottabad, Pakistan, by U.S. Navy SEALs.
2012
2013
  • Orphan Black is produced by Temple Street Productions, BBC America and Space.[58]
  • The Supreme Court strikes down the Defense of Marriage Act, which banned the federal recognition of same-sex marriages and refused to recognize the legal standing of proponents of Proposition 8, which resulted in the re-legalization of same-sex marriage in California.
  • Black Lives Matter emerges as a political movement, protesting against what it sees as widespread racial profiling, police brutality, and racial inequality in the United States criminal justice system.
2014
  • A grand jury decides not to charge Officer Darren Wilson in the shooting death of Michael Brown inciting protests and riots against racism and police brutality in the St. Louis area.
2015
  • Star Wars: The Force Awakens is released.[59]
  • Same-sex marriage is legalized in all 50 US states.
2016
  • Stranger Things is released on Netflix.
  • Rogue One is released.
  • U.S. presidential election, 2016: Donald Trump elected president, Mike Pence elected vice president
2017
  • Star Trek: Discovery is released on CBS All Access and Netflix.[60]
  • Star Wars: The Last Jedi is released.
  • A gunman opens fire at a Las Vegas Strip concert, killing 58 people and injuring 546. This is the deadliest mass shooting in modern U.S. history.
  • Film producer Harvey Weinstein is accused of sexual harassment in a New York Times expose, marking the beginning of the Me Too movement against sexual harassment and sexual assault.
2018
  • Solo: A Star Wars Story is released.
  • A gunman kills 17 people and injures 17 at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida.
  • Death of Stephen Hawking in Cambridge, United Kingdom. He left a legacy in theories of the universe and astrophysics.
2019
  • Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker is released.
  • U.S. Vice President Mike Pence orders NASA to fly Americans to the Moon within the next five years, using either government or private carriers.
  • The first image of a black hole is taken.

paragraphs.text:
This is a timeline of science fiction as a literary tradition. While the date of the start of science fiction is debated, this list includes a range of Ancient, Medieval, and Renaissance-era precursors and proto-science fiction as well, as long as these examples include typical science fiction themes and topoi such as
travel to outer space and encounter with alien life-forms.
